56b1f27d8ccbf6734debaabfb3bb7d76 (14:03): Hey, I'm trying to use a typed dataset as a dataobject(I usually use nhibernate)   and when I set it up it asks if I want to save the connection string in the app.config  and I say yes.  It creates the connectstring in the app config but then also creates a setting file with the connection string in it
56b1f27d8ccbf6734debaabfb3bb7d76 (14:03): is there a way to have it only use the app config rather than creating a settings file?
b25b0651e4b6e887e5194135d3692631 (14:03): Is it possible to include references in the binary, so they wont be as separate files and i can one big binary
56b1f27d8ccbf6734debaabfb3bb7d76 (14:04): mb: look up a program called ILMerge
b25b0651e4b6e887e5194135d3692631 (14:05): sontek, yeap, exactly what i wanted :) Thanks

49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:53): Hi all, I have a 6 byte chunk of text in a string, I was wondering if there is a simple way to convert it into a byte[6]
d233eb6bec08bdbe8cff48a70ff797b2 (14:53): dmh:  look into UTF text Encoding...
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:55): errr well look at the Encoding class and pick the appropriate encoding
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:55): because its gonna be different numbers of bytes for different encodings
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:55): ascii->bytes should work
f52974b56ef747f73d918e80a6de21c6 (14:55): dmh:  the other solution is to create a byte array the same length as the string, foreach thru the string and cast the chars into the bytes of the array...
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:56): then choose ascii ;)
f52974b56ef747f73d918e80a6de21c6 (14:56): dmh:  .net strings are unicode
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:56): Moridin8, thats what I'm currently doing, I just got to thinking, "I'm sure .NET has done this for me somewhere"
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:56): smellyhippy, eheh ok :]
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:56): yeah but why you GetBytes it'll convert to whichever encoding you want
12dfa5ef901d4d41a35e69d1d9464c70 (14:56): Yeah, strings are unicode by default, so is that a 3-char string? Or a 6 char string? Or 12 hex chars?
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:57): I have a string like this, "foo\(6 bytes)\(6 bytes)\EOT"
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:57): I have the 6 byte chunks seperated thanks to Split('\\')
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:57): in those 6 bytes, 4 bytes are for an ip, and 2 for a port
f52974b56ef747f73d918e80a6de21c6 (14:57): well, in .NET in memory its actually:  "foo\(12 bytes)\(12 bytes)\EOT"
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:57): yeah ... ignore what they're saying its just muddying the waters
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:58): just go check out the Encoding class
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:58): smellyhippy, well I follow it , so its ok
78dbc21d2902c96d3067f18f609ca04c (14:58): that'll do what yo uwant
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:58): yea, this is what I got so far
49d3650727f25f1831b88d97028cf8b4 (14:58): I dont udnerstand UTF it seems
12dfa5ef901d4d41a35e69d1d9464c70 (14:58): It confuses the crap out of me
